## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been following the development of Verus and I'm curious about the VerusHash algorithm. What was the goal of the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm, and how did it impact the performance of FPGAs and CPUs on the Verus network?

**AI Assistant:**
The goal of the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm was to equalize the performance of FPGAs and modern CPUs on the Verus network. It was designed to prevent FPGAs from dominating CPUs in terms of performance, and it succeeded in keeping FPGA performance at a price ratio of under 2x that of CPUs. Did you have any experience with mining or staking on the Verus network before VerusHash 2.0?

**User:**
That makes sense. I've also heard about VerusHash 2.1. What does it introduce, and how does it affect the balance between FPGAs and CPUs?

**AI Assistant:**
VerusHash 2.1 introduces an adjustment to the equalization technology, which is expected to tilt the balance more favorably towards CPUs while still allowing FPGAs to operate on the hash algorithm with minor modifications. This should make it even more accessible for people to participate in the Verus network without needing specialized hardware.

**User:**
I've heard that the Verus developers reached out to FPGA manufacturers. Why did they do that, and what was made available to them?

**AI Assistant:**
The Verus developers proactively reached out to FPGA manufacturers and made the new VerusHash 2.1 algorithm available to them, so that everyone would have an opportunity to mine and stake when the Verus economy begins to roll out and identity rewards start streaming from the network. This way, FPGA manufacturers can prepare and adapt their products to work with the new algorithm, ensuring a smooth transition for all participants.
What was the goal of the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm, and how did it impact the performance of FPGAs and CPUs on the Verus network?

The goal of the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm was to equalize the performance of FPGAs and modern CPUs on the Verus network. It was designed to prevent FPGAs from dominating CPUs in terms of performance, and it succeeded in keeping FPGA performance at a price ratio of under 2x that of CPUs.

# VerusHash 2.1

VerusHash 2.0 was the first algorithm to significantly equalize FPGAs dominance over CPUs, once they were introduced on the Verus network. While FPGAs were intentionally not blocked completely, which would simply drive the performance battle to the higher end and further into secret, the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm was developed to explicitly equalize FPGAs and modern CPUs and has met its original goals in keeping FPGA performance for the price under 2x of CPU. VerusHash 2.1 introduces an adjustment to the equalization technology, which we expect to tilt the balance a bit more favorably towards CPUs, while still enabling FPGAs to operate on the hash algorithm with minor modifications. Verus Developers have proactively reached out to FPGA manufacturers and made the new algorithm available to them, so that everyone will have an opportunity to mine and stake when the Verus economy starts to roll and identity rewards, which will not inflate the currency, but should far exceed the potential for block rewards, begin streaming from the network.
